headline: Trump-endorsed Joe Kent, who's challenging Rep. Jaime Herrera Beutler in a Republican primary, violated federal law by improperly disclosing his personal finances
author: Adam Wren

His submitted disclosure listed him earning $105,000 in 2021 from a full-time job, and separately, about $204,000 from a combination of his US Army pension, US Veterans Administration disability payments, and survivor benefits related to the death of his wife, Shannon Kent, a US Navy cryptologist who was killed in a suicide bombing during a mission in Syria.

It also identified dozens of lawmakers whose personal stock trades are discordant with their public responsibilities, such as members who craft anti-tobacco policy but invest in tobacco giants and others who receive plaudits from environmental groups for crafting policy aimed at combating the climate crisis  yet invest in fossil fuel companies.

Kent's tardy filing follows publication of Insider's "Conflicted Congress" project, which found that 57 members of Congress and at least 182 senior congressional aides have in recent months violated the federal Stop Trading on Congressional Knowledge Act of 2012 with late or missing financial disclosures.

"There have been some technical issues with getting access to the credentials required to file our report from the House Ethics Committee, and we expect to resolve that issue shortly," Matt Braynard, a spokesman for Kent, an ex-Green Beret who works at a tech startup, told Insider earlier this year.

A congressional candidate must file his or her financial disclosure, which details personal investments, debts, employment, and side income, shortly after raising or spending $5,000 in campaign cash, according to House ethics guidelines and federal law.

While such investigations are rare, the maximum civil penalty for such an offense is $66,190 while the maximum criminal penalty is one year in federal prison plus a fine of up to the same amount, according to the federal Ethics in Government Act.

Joe Kent, a Donald Trump-endorsed congressional candidate, violated a federal law by failing for months to publicly disclose his personal finances, only doing so after Insider asked him questions about his missing records.
The Committee on House Administration has scheduled a March 16 hearing on whether to ban members of Congress  and perhaps others, such as spouses of lawmakers  from trading individual stocks.
By law, congressional candidates may file their personal financial disclosures through the US House's electronic filing system or on paper via mail or hand delivery to the US Capitol.
Joe Kent, a Republican primary candidate for Washington's 3rd Congressional District, speaks during Justice For J6 rally, near the US Capitol in Washington, Saturday, Sept. 18, 2021.
The rally was planned by allies of former President Donald Trump and aimed at supporting the so-called "political prisoners" of the Jan. 6 insurrection at the U.S. Capitol.

Kent has been running against Herrera Beutler since early 2021 and his campaign raised nearly $1.4 million during 2021, according to FEC records.
Kent is running against Republican Rep. Jaime Herrera Beutler, a 6-term lawmaker from southwestern Washington state who voted to impeach Trump in January 2021.
But a candidate who "knowingly and willfully falsifies a statement or fails to file a statement" may be subject to investigation by the Department of Justice.
The standard, US House-issued fine for a late personal financial disclosure filing is $200, payable to the US Treasury.
His recent fundraising efforts include an event at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida, where tickets began at $1,000.
His disclosure noted he will receive another $40,000 upon the book's publication, which is scheduled for late 2022.
Kent easily surpassed that threshold by the middle of last year, according to Federal Election Commission records.
Rep. Jaime Herrera Beutler, a Republican from Washington, faces a strong GOP primary challenge from Joe Kent.

Nathan Howard/AP
Kent was months late publicly disclosing his personal finances, per federal law.
Kent also disclosed a $40,000 advance payment for a book he's writing about his late wife.
